speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Fernandez-Vargas versus Gonzales. Mr. Gossett.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Wouldn't it be the same result if Congress decided, for example, to take away one of the available methods of seeking 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- discretionary review, just saying, "We're not going to have that available anymore"?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that would be --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- a pretty easy case, wouldn't it? I mean, if you have a mechanism saying some -- an alien in this position can apply for, you know, this type of relief, this type of relief, or another, and they say, "Well, we're not going to allow this type of relief anymore. We're going to change those" -- was -- that's a pretty easy case, under Landgraf, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But why should that -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- why should that make a difference as to whether it's retroactive or not? I mean, if it -- it seems to me you look to the activity that it governs. And the activity that it governs is the deportation or removal from now on. Now, you could argue that -- if you want, that there are some due process violations in making that prospective law affect past activities as they do. I mean, let's -- one of the examples given in Landgraf, or at least in my concurrence in Landgraf, was a change of the law procedure so that expert testimony, which previously was not admissible, is now admissible. Now, the person who committed the crime that's involved in the next case that comes up when that new procedural rule is applied, he can say, "Well, you know, you've changed -- you've changed the rules on me. When I committed the crime, the expert testimony wasn't admissible. Now it is admissible. That's not fair." Well, whether it's fair or not is something we can inquire into under the due process clause, but nobody would say that that procedural change is retroactive. And it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- seems to me that's what's 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 going on here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That wasn't my point. My point --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- was, you look to the -- to the activity which is governed by the new law. In the case of the -- of the expert testimony, the activity governed is the trial, so that law applies prospectively to all future trials. So, also, in this case, this law applies prospectively to all future removals, QED. It is not retroactive. Now, you may have an argument, although I don't think it's a very good one, that there are due process problems involved in this prospective law. But I don't see how you can call the law retroactive.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't affect --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- doesn't affect his reentry at all. His reentry occurred. It -- how could it possibly have anything to do with his reentry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That would apply new penalties to the reentry. This law does not apply any new penalties to the reentry, it just -- it just establishes a new regime for removing the person who has reentered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Has any -- a number of courts have considered this question -- have any of them accepted your first -- your argument that the statute is clear that it is nonretroactive? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'd -- I'll have to look at those decisions. It was my impression that they did, indeed, hold that it was retroactive, but not on the ground that Congress had clearly spoken to the point, so that you didn't need any further inquiry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- I think that's because they were using the version of stage one that you are using, which includes, in the consideration of whether Congress has been clear, an inquiry into whether the -- whether the law is retroactive or not, which, as I understand it, should be left to stage two, exclusively.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Your analysis in your brief mingles the two. It says one of the factors that you can take into account in stage one is whether it's retroactive. And as I -- I don't understand Landgraf to speak that way. I thought you were supposed to use all other indicia of legislative intent, other than the normal rule against retroactivity, in deciding congressional intent, and then you go to stage two, which is where retroactivity comes in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but as the Government points out, that "either before or after" applied to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 when you had been deported --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- not to when you reentered. And what we're -- what you're arguing for here is a rule that goes from the time of reentry, not from the time of deportation. So, it's not really a parallel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's an --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that may be a reasonable inference, but I think it's a real stretch to say that it "clearly establishes." When you're talking about a statute, and you say something's "clear," you want to be able to point to actual words. And, on the other side, the Government points out that, elsewhere in IIRIRA, Congress specifically 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 delineates when it wants the statute to apply prospectively only. And they did not do that in this case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, I -- you lost --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- me there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm looking at page - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't how --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't see how that undermines their point that when Congress wants to specify that something "shall apply prospectively only," as they quote, "only with respect to entries occurring on or after a date," they spell it out. And they did not similarly spell it out in the provision on -- that you suggest is prospective only.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I wish we could get some new vocabulary. Terminology is destiny, and I really don't follow the discussion of speaking about whether it was prospective or retroactive. I don't think, whichever 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 way it applied, it is retroactive. But the issue still remains, Did Congress intend pre-IIRIRA reentries to be covered or not? I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- I would consider that still prospective, but just note my --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that I don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- go along with you when you force this terminology on me, whether Congress intended it to be retroactive. As I see it, the issue is whether Congress intended it to apply to reentries that occurred before IIRIRA was enacted. I would not consider that retroactive, but it's still an open question what Congress intended.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Aren't there several possible explanations for why Congress would leave the "before or after" language out of the -- out of the new provision? They might have wanted it just to be decided under the Landgraf framework. Isn't that one 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 possibility? Or they might have thought that "before or after" referred to the enactment of the INA, which would be 1952, and, therefore, irrelevant by the time this was passed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why would -- I find it difficult to understand why Congress wouldn't have wanted this to apply to illegal entrants who had come in before IIRIRA. Bear in mind, these are people who have been deported once, already deported once, and then, in violation of the law, come back in again. And there was a regime for deporting them, which allowed certain variations, which are eliminated by IIRIRA, permission for them to stay. You really think Congress wanted to keep faith with the people who had, already have -- having been deported once for illegal reentry - - illegal entry -- come in again -- and you think Congress says, "Oh, well, you know, we have to keep faith with these people who are violating our law, and not -- and not deport them except under the conditions that existed when they broke the law to reenter"? I find that a very -- what should I say? -- touching -- [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- attitude for Congress to have.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not only the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- disincentives.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They were trying to get out of the country people who were here illegally, two-time losers who were here illegally for the second time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- so here? I want to know, if your client had known about this law or gone to a lawyer and said, "What do I do now?" wouldn't the lawyer have said, or would he have said, "Just leave. Leave the country, quick, before you're caught. Now, when you get back to Mexico, you can apply and point 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- out you've married an American citizen, and then you'll be able to come in, in all likelihood." And if I'm right about that, the Act does not attach new consequences to old behavior, it attaches new consequences to new behavior; namely, the act of staying within the United States, when you could leave.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean when this particular

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- provision was passed --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- a week later, he goes to a lawyer, and the lawyer says, "You'd better get out of here fast, because if you're caught while you're here, you're married now, and you won't be able to take advantage of that. It would be terrible. So, go to Mexico. Then there is no problem." And if, in fact, I'm right, you see what I'm -- I find your argument excellent on the first part, but so is the Government's. So, I think there's a kind of wash there, so I'm looking to the second part. And there, you're just said, it attaches new consequences to old behavior. So, I'm asking you, if it doesn't attach the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 new consequences to old, but, necessarily, plus new behavior -- namely, remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Being -- if you get married -- if you're outside the country and you marry an American, you're married to an American and you can't come in for 5 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: As a result of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the initial deporting order.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, his choice is this Act 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 or -- in which case, you never can get back, if you're caught -- or go to Mexico, wait 5 years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ten to 20 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. I mean, he either stays in the United States --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in 10 to 20 years --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is caught.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you lose this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- case -- if you lose this case, then his choice would be: stay here, get caught, and you never can come back, or 10 to 20 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I see. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or go to Mexico, and you can come back in 5 years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, in this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- in this case, he was married after the effective date of the new statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Did Judge McConnell, in the Tenth Circuit, suggest -- because he discussed this -- suggest that the result might have been different if the marriage had been before?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why would that be consistent with his -- with his analysis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- it does point out that your argument is a difficult one, because this expectation that you argue for is that, number one, he has an expectation that he'd be able to adjust his status even after Congress has changed the law respecting reinstatement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: This is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- this is a far-reaching expectation on his part.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Am I wrong in thinking that readjustment based on his marriage was not one of the modes of relief that he could have had in '82 or -- that that didn't come in until much later, is that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, any -- so, that was a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 consequence that certainly wasn't taken away from him, because it wasn't there in '82.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Even though what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why would he think that? Why wouldn't he just think, being here illegally, he is subject to being deported under such rules as the country has for deporting people who are here illegally, whatever they may be, from time to time? That would be my expectation if I came in illegally, in violation of the law. I'm saying, "I'm here at the sufferance of the country. I shouldn't be here. And whatever rules they have for kicking me out are the rules that I'll have to abide by."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "I'm lucky not to be in 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 jail."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, in St. Cyr --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Under the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- was -- in St. Cyr, I think it was he pled guilty under one set of expectations, and that's what the Court fastened on. Isn't that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, he -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- might not have pled guilty if there was a different set of rules. I thought that was what drove the Court's opinion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If he had left voluntarily under the pre-'96 law, would he still have been subject to criminal prosecution for his prior illegal entry if he had later come back into the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Gossett. Mr. Srinivasan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And those --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Should --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And those provisions are specifically recited to apply only to reentrants after the effective date.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, let me go back to the criminal provision for a second. I take it your answer to the question I asked your brother a moment ago is that if the individual reenters, and, hence, has committed a criminal offense, and later voluntarily returns to -- in this case, to Mexico, that the criminal violation, in effect, would not, in any sense, be canceled out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And that if he returned, he could be prosecuted for the prior reentry. And I suppose, in theory -- I don't know what the extradition treaty is -- in theory, he might be subject to extradition for it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The odd way to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: There's no forgiveness --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't want to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't want us to decide it on that ground, do you, so that all future cases you'll have to decide whether he came in before '94 or after '94, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but your point, though -- I mean, someone illegally reentering at that time might not have had a reasonable expectation of the availability of discretionary relief. On the other hand, someone in the -- a petitioner's position, after all that had happened, did have a fairly good case under those provisions that were no longer available.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, and someone entering says, "Well, obviously, if I'm detained the day after I enter, I'm not going to have a very good case. On the other hand, if I'm not, and I happen to make a life here, and I'm here for 20 years, and I get married and I have a child, I'm going to have a strong case," and he's going to -- he's willing to take his chances.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did you say '84 or '94? I couldn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And the executive couldn't weigh that. You say, categorically, it -- there's no - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- no possibility for discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, could the -- could the INS have just stayed its hand for -- in --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can't imagine that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I say, I cannot imagine that. No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- but I -- I didn't understand this now. I guess I don't. Forget the '94/'96 periods.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose it stayed the same throughout. Would you say, then, that someone who came illegally into the country, and he's caught, and he's married to an American, there's no possibility he can stay, no matter what, no matter how appealing? Is that the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm -- yes, but you're talking technically.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Maybe there's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- some other way you could stay. What's the other way? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Which was what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- then it comes to the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- same thing. So, that -- what I'm thinking is that a person who is here, and they marry an American -- all right? -- they marry a citizen. Now, before this Act was passed, there was a way that if they're really good -- let's assume they're the best human beings around, and the Attorney General finds all that out, and everybody knows this is like a saint, and they say, "Okay, you behave well enough. You can stay." Now, after the Act is passed, all those relevant actions have taken place in '86, long before. Now, there's absolutely nothing they can do. All they can do is go home. And now I've learned that when they go home, they will be told, "You cannot come back, no 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 matter what, for 5 years." Now, that's a pretty harsh consequence, to separate yourself from your family or have your family come to a foreign country. So, if I think the first part of this is a wash, you have a great argument, they have a great argument, and I look to the second part, does it attach new consequences to old and unchangeable behavior? I say, yes, it sure does. Now, why doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ah. So, then, you're saying the answer I got before was wrong --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that, in fact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- I now have my client in, he's come after IIRIRA has been enacted, and he says, "I've heard about this in IIRIRA, and what in heaven's name am I supposed to do?" And the lawyer says, "Get out fast, next train. Go back. And if you get across that border, you're safe. Because at that point, you can apply; and you're a saint, and you've been married, they'll let you right in, because they'll find out." That's what your view of the law is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It must be the one way or the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, in -- and this is not -- I was saying the question -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- would be, is this Act attaching consequences to old things that you couldn't do anything about? And you're saying, "Not entirely. You can. You can leave. In which case, you'll be no worse off, except for the train fare."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That person has not illegally reentered the United States? He's gone back, but he did illegally reenter the United States. He wouldn't be covered by the same provision that we're talking about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And even if he was, that was waivable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just as he doesn't automatically get admitted because he's married, does he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's discretionary, as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- one discretion --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and another discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the instance --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- of a child --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- who had -- he had a relationship to a child in the United States. And couldn't that have counted for suspension of deportation or removal, whatever terms I use now? Did

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- for a hardship claim, a parent-child relationship?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He was here -- he was here for 20 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- 20 years, though.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it farfetched, in view of the history of now I- -- before INS, weren't there a great many people who got here and -- just as this Petitioner -- who just lived here for years and years, and were never disturbed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or, put more starkly, if I continue to violate the law for 7 years, I can count on this kind of treatment. That's an odd reliance interest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- this elementary --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- an elementary question, just to be sure we all agree on this? You do agree, do you not, that if, in 1997, Congress passed a statute that said you should get an extra $50 penalty for having come in, back in 1981, that would not be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And there's sort of an irony in the fact that the actual consequence here is a great deal more serious.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which is constitutionally prohibited. But the consequences here are permitted. I understand the analysis. It's like just saying we take away one ground for staying that we didn't have before. But looking at it in kind of a basic sense, that seems -- it's a fairly serious thing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- that happens, and it effects an awful lot of people, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you read the Tenth Circuit opinion as indicated it might have had a different result if he had been married before the enactment of the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How does that fit with the court's theory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How does it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure that gives the other side the -- you know, the benefit of their argument. I think what they're arguing is not just that it was deleted, but that it was not replaced by -- whether "before or after," and then filling in the date of IIRIRA, rather than the date of the INA. I have -- nobody thinks that they would leave in June 27, 1952, but why wouldn't they have substituted, for that, the date of this new legislation, the date of IIRIRA? I think that's the point he's making.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And isn't there something to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just getting rid of old language that was no longer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- or intentionally not adding new language. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Gossett, you have 2 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, a person who just leaves voluntarily, having reentered illegally, cannot come back for 5 years, no matter what, under 1156(a)(6)(B).

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That was repealed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.
